title: Design Biotop

author: Ana Kyra Bekš, SERVIS 8, Zavod za inovacije, izobraževanje in delavnice oblikovanja storitev
Saša Kerkoš, Tretaroka / 3rd Hand

segmentation: Hello, I'm Sasha and I'm representing this.
I buy a top but this year we we also invited Anna Keira Bitch and Marko Horvat from Service 8.
Their service designers from Louisiana to help US process the workshop.
I will be very quick, just having some having some introduction and then Anna will say more about how the process went in the workshop and the conclusions.
Um, we started the process.

This about thinking topics and from the last years experience working with the Municipality of Ljubljana Cultural Tourism strategy was coming out strong because it was a new upcoming strategy that was actually written an let's say published this year and we looked into this cultural tourism an with discussions with different individuals from Municipality of Ljubljana and beyond.
We came to the conclusion that there is a lot of parts and a lot of things inside of this strategy that.
Still do not, let's say, have really common ground or are not clearly defined.
For instance, the position of creative industries in the bigger picture of of cultural tourism and so on so.
So just this I'm already talking about the background stories and experience.
So to embed ourselves as as as organization that works from outside the municipality.
It was a little bit of a challenge to come up with good teams from.
I would say from the municipality, especially because all, let's say that the different departments have different strengths and different.
I would say responsibilities so there's only few departments that are actually really really important.
We invited some of them and at the end we participated with the Tourism Board of Banana and the Department for Culture of Municipalities in Louisiana.
We also had large is my.
How do you translate that young Dragons?
It is also the cities organization that embeds youth in different projects, so we also had someone coming from there so that the youth could also be heard in this process.
Um?
We are coming there.
So mentors, we have a different strategy and perhaps then maybe some of other partners of future hit actual platform.
We usually mismatch skills and knowledge from different mentors so that we can gather different points of views and perspectives into the mix.
And that's how we can grow stronger points of view because they come from different angles.

Our mentors were used a coupon and Yonatan Hilden from Finland, Shereen and Kimberly, from displays designers who are working with an invisibles together with the refugees and the crisis that is going on there.
An pallapalla patellae who is an architect and researcher that works across different places.
I don't even know how to describe those places.
There's so many of them, but all of them have something in common and that's.

The understanding of creative thinking and design processes from the last years experience with young commentors, we have seen that if we do not have experienced mentors in the process with workshops with different, I would say age groups and so on.
There could be a little challenging running different age groups and work with them because sometimes as we know young and old or different ages don't match together.
So this year we made sure that what we do bring together with all these mentors is that they have skills and knowledge how to run creativity based processes.
Also, we had an, uh, an Marco from service A.

There are service designers you can say more about herself later from Ljubljana to run an monitor and process the work from mentors to the workshop and beyond, and eyelash Windisch who was a consultant for the data team.
If I go back to the mentors they were kind of coming from different fields, use and.

Jonathan are coming from the data design an information design parts and they're really good with understanding the city from the perspective of data sharing and Kimberly from participation, how to include different audiences into the mix to get the best result out an how to bring the voices of the people of Louisiana closer to the municipality and Paola Petilli too.
Actually bring the research and a different angle of architecture and heritage into the city.
And now I will give my word to Anna and thank you for having me here.

Hello everyone, my name is Anna Keira and Sasha said I come from Service 8 which is non profit organization an we work with design thinking applied to the services so service design and with customer experience design an we were invited by Sasha and the other two girls to help set the workshops and then run the workshops.
So just to give you a bit of background half a year before the actual workshops happen we started talking with mentors.
So we were looking at the strategies we were looking at different materials and we were exploring which topics might be interesting and then based on that we concluded three types of workshop then.
Then we run last week.
So Serene and Kimberly had a workshop on Community inclusion, so participatory design.
How could we include all the stakeholders when we design strategies their title of their workshop was who is the city and tourism for.
Use on unit and so they were looking at.
Cultural tourism from a data perspective, they were exploring.
You will see later on accommodations.
How do people travel, how much money they spend and visualizing those that data?
And then Paolo was trying to redefine or to put doubt in what the culture and tourism is.
They were exploring monuments and perception of monuments and perception of tourism.
So that was interesting to get really three different points of view on the same topic.
So who's the city tourism form?
Um?
They based their workshop on personas that were made for the strategy for the culture tourism and they were exploring who might also else be involved in the process.
And the result of the workshop was.
A very rough template of a workshop that tourism board could conduct with all the other relevant stakeholders.
So from people that live in the city, tourists, people that offer tourism products or services.
So mostly they were thinking about groups of people that are maybe in a minority.
So people that have disabilities they were thinking about the space or where should these workshops happen?
What kind of outputs can come out of these workshops?
They were thinking about possible negative scenarios and how to respond.
Anna Sasha said they're going to use that knowledge and that experience, I think in a month when they're going to do their first workshop.
With you saw and uniton.
It they started off with asking questions so they were thinking about OK.
So if we think of Ljubljana, which parts of Libyan are interesting?
Just before the workshop when we went for dinner, you son Yonatan were searching for Instagram photos and trying to see what are the most often hashtags?
Where are the pictures being taken?
Just to see with all this day that if there's a pattern or if there's something that cannot be seen otherwise.
But at the end what they chose.
They were exploring Airbnb, so on the left side you can see a map.
The heat map of Airbnb versus regular hostels and hotels.

It's interesting because you can see there are some areas of land that are not covered by traditional accommodations on the right side you see the nearest bicycle, so the public bike transport to cultural or tourism attractions.
They were comparing Air BNB from Ljubljana to Zagreb, which was interesting that we have much more expense, expensive, very being beaten Zagreb this.
And they were looking at what kind of prices they are and what kind of satisfaction visitors have.
Sorry.
This was nearly yeah, so this data has never been looked at before.
This gather data has never been shown, so they were gathering all this data throughout the workshop and was the first time they could see this, right?
So there's a big lack of data or knowledge how to process their data and use it for strategies or any other kind of work.
And the third workshop may be the most abstract one with support structures for thinking heritage.
Which.
They were breaking down pictures of tourism, promotional booklets and they were trying to see how does Ljubljana wants to be perceived and how people perceive and how that affects one another.
And then they were trying to use that same strategy to make their own monuments or their own.
Propaganda, so one of the things they come up with is the statue of Friends Mickler Switch, whose head was taken because I think it was before a front front.
You know, yes?
So because of him.
History and political stuff.
His head was removed and replaced so they made a new proposition of the last head having its own monument.
So where they were, they were trying to rethink some things that seems very obvious to us.
So looking forward as such, I said we wanted to make this something that's not going to end as the workshop ends.
I think next week we're going to meet with the tourism board who they were really excited with.
The new data with the new approach, and we're going to try to see if we can work together and try to continue this.
So for the Community workshops, there's still a lot of stuff to be done.
Also, with the data collected.
So if there was a way that this data could be collected in the future and process, it might give us a lot of insight on how our city works or how people act in the city.
And This Is Us.
Thank you.
